articles.headline: Divisions Are Clear as Obama and Netanyahu Discuss Peace
articles.snippet: In a meeting with President Obama, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel listed a series of nonnegotiable conditions for a deal with Palestinians.
articles.abstract: In a meeting with President Obama, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel listed a series of nonnegotiable conditions for a deal with Palestinians.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told President Obama on Friday that he shared his vision for a peace between Israelis and Palestinians, and then promptly listed a series of nonnegotiable conditions that have kept the two sides at an impasse for years.

articles.headline: For Gay Employees, an Equalizer
articles.snippet: More businesses are reaching into their own pockets to pay for an extra tax that gay employees owe on their partners’ health insurance.
articles.abstract: More businesses are reaching into their own pockets to pay for an extra tax that gay employees owe on their partners’ health insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: The battle to legalize same-sex marriage may be dominating the headlines, but that issue could take years to resolve. More immediately, a growing number of companies have taken it upon themselves to make life a little more equal for their gay employees.

articles.headline: A Bad Year for Car Bargains
articles.snippet: With the average price for a new car in the United States edging toward $30,000, some executives fear that sticker shock could stall the industry’s recent comeback.
articles.abstract: With the average price for a new car in the United States edging toward $30,000, some executives fear that sticker shock could stall the industry’s recent comeback.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The average price for a new car in the United States is edging toward $30,000, as automakers remain stingy with discounts and there just are not enough of the most popular vehicles available.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Sexual Affronts Are a Known Hotel Hazard
articles.snippet: Many people were shocked by the charges that the head of the I.M.F. sexually assaulted a hotel housekeeper, but those in the industry say that sexual affronts happen regularly.
articles.abstract: Many people were shocked by the charges that the head of the I.M.F. sexually assaulted a hotel housekeeper, but those in the industry say that sexual affronts happen regularly.
articles.lead_paragraph: A lot of people were shocked by the charges that the head of the International Monetary Fund sexually assaulted a hotel housekeeper in New York last weekend.

articles.headline: Regulators Find Design Flaws in New Reactors
articles.snippet: The Nuclear Regulator Commission is asking Westinghouse to fix its calculations and to explain why it submitted flawed information in the first place.
articles.abstract: The Nuclear Regulator Commission is asking Westinghouse to fix its calculations and to explain why it submitted flawed information in the first place.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a setback for the only model of nuclear reactor for which ground has been broken in the United States, government regulators have found additional problems with the design of its shield building, a crucial component, the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Friday.

articles.headline: States Seeking New Registries for Criminals
articles.snippet: As laws mandating registration of offenders proliferate, so do questions about their cost, effectiveness and fairness.
articles.abstract: As laws mandating registration of offenders proliferate, so do questions about their cost, effectiveness and fairness.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers around the country are pushing for online registries, like those used for sex offenders, to track the whereabouts of people convicted of a wide variety of crimes, from arson and drunken driving to methamphetamine manufacturing and animal abuse.

articles.headline: Apple Is Called Poised to Offer ‘Cloud’ Music
articles.snippet: Apple has entered the final stages of negotiations with major record labels and music publishers for a service that will allow people to listen to their music stored on the Web.
articles.abstract: Apple has entered the final stages of negotiations with major record labels and music publishers for a service that will allow people to listen to their music stored on the Web.
articles.lead_paragraph: For tens of millions of iTunes users, listening to music may soon get a lot easier.
articles.byline: By Ben Sisario and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: On Tyson’s Face, It’s Art. On Film, a Legal Issue.
articles.snippet: A suit over Mike Tyson’s tattoo sported by a character in the movie “The Hangover Part II” could offer the first rulings on copyrighted works on people’s bodies.
articles.abstract: A suit over Mike Tyson’s tattoo sported by a character in the movie “The Hangover Part II” could offer the first rulings on copyrighted works on people’s bodies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hollywood is accustomed to lawsuits over salaries, movie credits, even half-baked concepts that become movies. And now a studio may be going to court over a tattoo — or at least over the original concept of the tattoo.

articles.headline: Backing Her Man With Impressive Resources
articles.snippet: Anne Sinclair, wife of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, has joined the unhappy club of wives standing by their man in the face of a crescendo of tales of sexual betrayal.
articles.abstract: Anne Sinclair, wife of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, has joined the unhappy club of wives standing by their man in the face of a crescendo of tales of sexual betrayal.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — She was much more famous than her husband, and much wealthier, too.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Maïa de la Baume

articles.headline: Obama’s Peace Tack Contrasts With Key Aide, Friend of Israel
articles.snippet: Dennis B. Ross, who favors painstaking diplomacy and eschews game-changing plays, is the chief Middle East adviser to a president with bold instincts.
articles.abstract: Dennis B. Ross, who favors painstaking diplomacy and eschews game-changing plays, is the chief Middle East adviser to a president with bold instincts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Five days ago, during a closed-door meeting with a group of Middle East experts, administration officials, and journalists, King Abdullah II of Jordan gave his assessment of how Arabs view the debate within the Obama administration over how far to push Israel on concessions for peace with the Palestinians.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Guard Dog to the Stars (Legally Speaking)
articles.snippet: Martin Singer and his law firm have emerged as the foremost protectors of celebrities, including Charlie Sheen.
articles.abstract: Martin Singer and his law firm have emerged as the foremost protectors of celebrities, including Charlie Sheen.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES

articles.headline: It Teetered, It Tottered, It Was Bound to Fall Down
articles.snippet: NovaStar Financial was a microcosm of what would set the stage for the 2008 credit crisis, a new book says.
articles.abstract: NovaStar Financial was a microcosm of what would set the stage for the 2008 credit crisis, a new book says.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Joshua Rosner

articles.headline: Promise of Arab Uprisings Is Threatened by Divisions
articles.snippet: From Egypt to Syria, tensions over religion and clans have threatened uprisings that once seemed to promise a new sense of national identity built on the idea of citizenship.
articles.abstract: From Egypt to Syria, tensions over religion and clans have threatened uprisings that once seemed to promise a new sense of national identity built on the idea of citizenship.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The revolutions and revolts in the Arab world, playing out over just a few months across two continents, have proved so inspirational to so many because they offer a new sense of national identity built on the idea of citizenship.
articles.byline: By Anthony Shadid and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: The Gossip Machine, Churning Out Cash
articles.snippet: Stars and dimmer lights deal in a world of dirt and money, not always unwillingly.
articles.abstract: Stars and dimmer lights deal in a world of dirt and money, not always unwillingly.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In late July 2010, the Southampton, N.Y., police charged Michael Lohan, the father of the actress Lindsay Lohan, with physically harassing his fiancée. When the news hit on the gossip Web site TMZ, Mr. Lohan was at the Sunset Tower in Los Angeles, where he had been on the interview circuit discussing his daughter’s imprisonment stemming from drunken-driving charges.

articles.headline: Old Soviet Nuclear Site in Asia Has Unlikely Sentinel: The U.S.
articles.snippet: Western scientists are aiming to keep terrorists away from debris the Soviets left behind during their atomic tests, with the fear that the materials could be used for nuclear devices.
articles.abstract: Western scientists are aiming to keep terrorists away from debris the Soviets left behind during their atomic tests, with the fear that the materials could be used for nuclear devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: KURCHATOV, Kazakhstan — Twenty years after the Soviet Union collapsed and tens of thousands of soldiers abandoned their posts at this remote site in northeastern Kazakhstan, the footprints of another great power — the United States — are increasingly visible.

articles.headline: Obama Presses Israel to Make ‘Hard Choices’
articles.snippet: The president, speaking to the nation’s foremost pro-Israel lobbying group, repeated his call for Palestinian statehood based on Israel’s pre-1967 borders adjusted for land swaps.
articles.abstract: The president, speaking to the nation’s foremost pro-Israel lobbying group, repeated his call for Palestinian statehood based on Israel’s pre-1967 borders adjusted for land swaps.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama struck back at Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in a speech to a pro-Israel lobbying group on Sunday, defending his stance that talks over a Palestinian state should be focused on Israel’s pre-1967 borders, along with negotiated land swaps, and challenging Israel to “make the hard choices” necessary to bring about a stable peace.

articles.headline: Talk Show Ends, and Oprah Moves On
articles.snippet: Oprah Winfrey’s last show will be the biggest such moment since Johnny Carson left “The Tonight Show.”
articles.abstract: Oprah Winfrey’s last show will be the biggest such moment since Johnny Carson left “The Tonight Show.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Oprah Winfrey has taped more than 5,000 episodes of her daytime talk show, transforming television and trying to teach millions of viewers how to live life with purpose along the way. She has one more to go. She says she feels relieved.

articles.headline: TV Justice Thrives on Fear
articles.snippet: On Nancy Grace’s television show, the presumption of innocence has found a willful and angry enemy.
articles.abstract: On Nancy Grace’s television show, the presumption of innocence has found a willful and angry enemy.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, it was announced that “America’s Most Wanted,” hosted by John Walsh, the longest running perp walk in television history, would no longer be regularly broadcast on Fox. With the future of Mr. Walsh’s hunt for bad guys uncertain, who will speak for the victims of crime?

articles.headline: Female Magazine Fans Flock to Nook Color
articles.snippet: There is a bit of a gender shakeout in devices: tablets have an edge with men, while women seem to prefer e-readers.
articles.abstract: There is a bit of a gender shakeout in devices: tablets have an edge with men, while women seem to prefer e-readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as the iPad remains the favorite son of the magazine business, publishers are discovering that the Barnes & Noble Nook Color is a very promising younger daughter.

articles.headline: Analysts Wary of LinkedIn’s Stock Surge
articles.snippet: While some Internet stocks like LinkedIn are achieving eye-raising valuations, many people are still hesitant to proclaim that the markets are on the cusp of another tech bubble.
articles.abstract: While some Internet stocks like LinkedIn are achieving eye-raising valuations, many people are still hesitant to proclaim that the markets are on the cusp of another tech bubble.
articles.lead_paragraph: What are shares of LinkedIn really worth?

articles.headline: Yahoo’s Emphasis Is ‘Better,’ Not ‘New’
articles.snippet: Yahoo’s product chief, Blake Irving, told employees to “celebrate success, not launches.” The company has focused on improving existing services, like Flickr.
articles.abstract: Yahoo’s product chief, Blake Irving, told employees to “celebrate success, not launches.” The company has focused on improving existing services, like Flickr.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — In listing his biggest accomplishments as Yahoo’s product chief, Blake Irving gave an answer that speaks to the company’s painful legacy of layoffs, aimlessness and stalled growth.

articles.headline: As Lenders Hold Homes in Foreclosure, Sales Are Hurt
articles.snippet: The nation’s biggest banks and mortgage lenders have amassed a glut of foreclosed homes that threatens to deepen the housing slump.
articles.abstract: The nation’s biggest banks and mortgage lenders have amassed a glut of foreclosed homes that threatens to deepen the housing slump.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL MIRAGE, Ariz. — The nation’s biggest banks and mortgage lenders have steadily amassed real estate empires, acquiring a glut of foreclosed homes that threatens to deepen the housing slump and create a further drag on the economic recovery.

articles.headline: Daniels Is Out, in Another Jolt to G.O.P. Field
articles.snippet: After Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana said he would not run for president, a debate began over whether there would be a candidate able to unseat President Obama.
articles.abstract: After Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana said he would not run for president, a debate began over whether there would be a candidate able to unseat President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The announcement Sunday by Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana that he would not run for the Republican presidential nomination ended one major chapter of uncertainty in the race but ignited new debate over whether the current field contains a candidate capable of beating President Obama next year.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Free Speech on Twitter Faces Test
articles.snippet: A British soccer star’s affair became gossip online but was blocked from the media, fueling a debate about privacy.
articles.abstract: A British soccer star’s affair became gossip online but was blocked from the media, fueling a debate about privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — What began as seamy gossip about an affair between a famous British soccer player and a reality TV star has quickly become another test over how far the rights to privacy and free speech extend online, where social media operate in countries with vastly different laws.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: Sealift Extends Lifeline to a Rebel City in Libya
articles.snippet: An impromptu fleet is sailing out of Benghazi, ferrying supplies to rebel-held Misurata.
articles.abstract: An impromptu fleet is sailing out of Benghazi, ferrying supplies to rebel-held Misurata.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABOARD AL IRADAH 6 — Near midnight, in the darkness of the deliberately unlit Misurata harbor, the tugboat’s crew loosened its lines from the pier and pulled them aboard.

articles.headline: A Rush to Protect Patients, Then Bloody Chaos
articles.snippet: Rescuers worked to find people still alive after a tornado destroyed much of Joplin, Mo., including a hospital.
articles.abstract: Rescuers worked to find people still alive after a tornado destroyed much of Joplin, Mo., including a hospital.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOPLIN, Mo. — When the warning — “Execute Condition Gray!” — blared through the halls of St. John’s Regional Medical Center, nurses began rolling patients’ beds into the hallways, as they had been trained to do time and again in this tornado-prone region.
articles.byline: By A. G. Sulzberger and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Sony Swings to Big Loss After Natural Disasters
articles.snippet: The loss, to be announced in a year-end earnings report on Thursday, would be Sony’s largest in 16 years.
articles.abstract: The loss, to be announced in a year-end earnings report on Thursday, would be Sony’s largest in 16 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The March 11 earthquake and tsunami probably pushed Sony to a $3.2 billion loss in the just-ended fiscal year, the electronics and entertainment giant warned Monday. It was the latest Japanese manufacturer to report a huge financial hit from the disaster.
